title-group.article-title: Parameters for an Elasto-Plasto-Damage Model for the Stress–Strain Behavior of Cohesive Soils

article-meta.aff: Department of Civil Engineering, KFUPM, Dhahran 31261, Saudi Arabia

abstract.p: This article presents a constitutive model for cohesive soils that exhibits the post-peak strain-softening behavior. The model combines the elements of plasticity with damage mechanics to simulate the stress–strain behavior. The total strain increment is composed of an elasto-damage strain increment and a plastic strain increment. The post-peak stress drop is captured by the elasto-damage formulation, while the plasticity is superimposed beyond the elastic range. The elasto-damage strain increment is found using the elasto-damage formulation, while the plastic strain increment is found using either the Drucker–Prager classical plasticity model or as a function of the damage strain. To calibrate this model, an experimental program was conducted on a cohesive soil at different densities and water contents. The various physical and mechanical properties of this soil were determined. Triaxial compression tests, unconfined compression test, and hydrostatic tests were performed, in order to obtain the model parameters at different conditions. These parameters were used to calibrate the model, which was coded in FORTRAN computer programs to simulate the stress–strain behavior of cohesive soils. The model was verified and found to be a good predictor of the response of cohesive soil for the selected stress path.

sec.title: INTRODUCTION
sec.p: The damage mechanics technique has been applied successfully to various materials such as metals and concrete. It was assumed that a purely brittle material unloads in an elasto-damage manner, with nonlinearity caused by degradation in the modulus of elasticity due to damage. However, a purely elasto-plastic material will always show permanent deformation when unloaded after yielding. In the case of soils, plasticity plays a significant role in addition to damage. Actual soil behavior is neither of a purely elasto-damage type nor of a purely elasto-plastic type, but is assumed to be a combination of both.

In this article, an elasto-plasto-damage model was developed for the stress–strain behavior of a cohesive soil (marl). This is another extension of the work of the authors (Al-Shayea et al., 2003), and hence the basic background and theoretical formulations are presented herein with minor modifications for the completeness of the presentation. The model was customized for the application of conventional triaxial compression (CTC) because of the abundant use of this test for the determination of soil strength. The marl investigated in this work has a damage effect, which is the degradation in material compliance along with the plasticity effect, which is the irrecoverable permanent deformation. The strain-softening behavior is considered to be a combination of elasto-damage and plastic behavior. Figure 1 represents schematically the various strain components. The plasticity is assumed to cause no degradation in material compliance, so a perfectly elasto-plastic material will always unload at the same modulus as the initial modulus, but along a different path, after yielding has taken place (path 1), which results in permanent strain following complete unloading. On the other hand, the elasto-damage strain is assumed to be completely recoverable, and is composed of elastic and damage parts. Such a material unloads with a degraded modulus of elasticity after the occurrence of damage, and returns to a zero stress and strain state, as shown by path 2 in Figure 1. The damage part of the strain is assumed to occur due to an increase in compliance caused by the damage. The actual soil behavior is neither of these two types. The actual soil material is assumed to follow path 3 (Figure 1), so that there will be elastic strain, damage strain due to degradation in initial modulus of elasticity, and plastic strain due to dislocation and permanent readjustment of the soil particles. Figure 1.
Schematic unloading paths with ideal plastic deformation (path 1), perfectly brittle behavior (path 2), and combined plasticity and damage (path 3) (Abu-Labdeh and Voyiadjis 1993).

At a particular value of the stress increment, the total strain increment was obtained by adding the elasto-damage strain increment and the plastic strain increment, as found from the respective formulations. The total strain increment (dε) is composed of the elastic strain increment (dεe), the damage strain increment (dεd), and the plastic strain increment (dεp) that is: (1)

In this work, the elasto-damage component of the strain was obtained from the elasto-damage formulation derived for the CTC test. The post-peak stress-drop was also obtained by the same elasto-damage formulation. The plastic strain was found by two different methods. In method 1, the plastic strain was taken as some factor times the damage strain. In method 2, the Drucker–Prager model was derived for the conventional triaxial test case, from which the plastic strain was calculated.

A rigorous analytical formulation was carried out to obtain the elasto-plasto-damage stress–strain behavior by the two methods. Also, an extensive experimental program was conducted on marl soil at different densities, exhibiting a post-peak strain-softening behavior, to find the model parameters. In addition, FORTRAN programs were developed based on the analytical formulations to simulate the behavior of compacted marl, which was compared with the experimental results.

sec.title: LITERATURE REVIEW
sec.p: The theory of continuum damage mechanics (CDM) proposed by Kachanov (1986, 2006) has been applied successfully to different materials, and is used to predict both strain-hardening and strain-softening types of behavior. The damage phenomenon and damage variable can be explained by considering a damaged body, with (S) being the overall cross sectional area defined by the normal (n→). Within the same cross section, the cracks and cavities have intersections of different shapes, with area (SD). These microcracks and cavities cannot resist the externally applied load. The effective area (S~) is obtained by subtracting the area of the voids (SD) from the total area (S).
The damage variable (ωn), associated with the normal (n→), represents the area of the cracks and cavities per unit surface in a plane perpendicular to the normal (n→) and is given as: (2)

Therefore, ωn = 0 corresponds to the undamaged state, while ωn = 1 corresponds to the rupture of the element in two parts; a value between 0 and 1 characterizes the occurrence of damage. The effective area gives rise to the effective stress concept in damage mechanics as given by Kachanov (2006), as the mean density of the forces acting on the elementary surface that effectively resists the applied load.

A practical soil model should be such that it involves a minimum possible number of parameters and be still able to predict the behavior of the material. The hyperbolic model (Kodner, 1963) is the most frequently used model for predicting the stress–strain behavior of soil. The limitation of the model lies in its inability to predict the post peak stress-drop; that is, strain softening.

Chow and Wang (1987) presented the development of an anisotropic elastic damage theory. They presented a modified damage effect tensor M~(D) for the effective stress equations to take into account the effect of anisotropic material damage. The reduction of the proposed tensor to a scalar for the isotropic damage state occurred not only in the principal stress direction, but also in any arbitrary coordinate system. The model was applied to metals.

To account of the plasticity effect, Chow and Wang (1988) further developed a generalized damage characteristic tensor (J~), to characterize anisotropic damage evolution in combination with plasticity. The tensorial equation of the damage evolution for tensor (J~) reduced to a scalar if the damage state was isotropic.

Following the developments in metals, Suaris et al. (1990) presented a damage model for monotonic and cyclic loading of concrete. The compliance tensor presented for stress strain relationship was dependent on accumulated damage. Damage evolution was obtained by using a loading surface (f) and bounding surface (F), along with a limit fracture surface (fo) defined in terms of the thermodynamic force conjugates of the damage variables, Figure 2. The model was applied to the case where the principal stresses and the strain axes coincided and did not rotate as the material deformed. Figure 2.
Limit fracture, loading and bounding surfaces in strain energy release space after Suaris et al. (1990).

Abu-Labdeh and Voyiadjis (1993) presented a plasticity damage model for concrete under cyclic multi-axial loading. The model was based on the bounding surface concept and combined plastic deformations with deformations due to damage. The total strain increment (dε) was divided into an elastic strain increment (dεe), a damage strain increment (dεd), and a plastic strain increment (dεp) at a particular value of stress.
Crouch and Wolf (1995) presented a constitutive model which treated clays, silts, and sand in their loose and dense states under both monotonic and complex stress paths within a single framework.
Karr et al. (1996) presented a brittle damage model for rock. In their model the effect of material degradation on the failure mechanism of brittle damage materials was investigated.

Gupta and Bergstrom (1997) presented a model for the compressive failure of rocks via a process of shear faulting. The model presented the progressive growth of damage that led to the formation of a critical fault nucleus, which grew unstably into its own plane by fracturing the grain boundaries.

Khan et al. (1998) proposed a constitutive model for concrete based on CDM, using the damage-effect tensor (M~) with a damage magnification factor α and β for tension and compression, respectively. The bounding surface concept, as introduced by Dafalias and Popov (1977), was used for the constitutive relationship and evolution of damage. The proposed model was able to identify the degradation in elastic properties, strain softening, the gain in strength under increasing confinement, and different behaviors in tension and compression.
Al-Shayea et al. (2003) quantified parameters for a plastic-damage model for the stress–strain behavior of two types of soils at maximum density only.

sec.title: Damage Formulation
sec.p: For the case of CTC test, σ2 = σ3 = σcell = constant, and the deviator stress in the axial direction (Δσ1: = σ1 − σcell) is changing. This case reduces to a uniaxial case. The deviator part of the of the stress vector, causing the shearing failure in the cylindrical soil specimen, is given as: (3)

For the CTC test, the compliance and stiffness terms for i = j = 1, and with ω1 = 0 and ω2 = ω3 = ω can be shown to be: (4) where, Eo is the initial modulus of elasticity, and β is the peak strength factor or damage magnification factor.

The strain energy density (ρW) for the deviator part of the CTC test, which is to be predicted by the formulation, is given as: (5) where, (C~ij) is the effective compliance matrix, the inverse of the effective stiffness matrix, (D~ij). The relationship between axial stress (Δσ1), strain (ε1), and the strain energy (W) gives: (6)
Substituting Equation (6) into Equation (5) gives: (7)
The thermodynamic force conjugates (Ri) can be obtained by taking the negative derivative of the strain energy density with respect to the damage variables (ωn) as: (8) (9)

R1 is set to zero because negative values for Ri are inadmissible in view of the nonnegativity of the thermodynamic conditions. This further implies that damage in direction ‘1’ is also zero, that is, ω1 = 0. For the CTC test, ω2 = ω3 = ω due to symmetry. The final expression for strain energy release rate at onset of damage (Ro), for the CTC test, is given as: (10) where, Δσ is some percentage of the peak deviator strength (Δσ1,p).
The final expression for critical value of strain energy release rate at failure (Rc), for the CTC test, is given as: (11)
For the deviator stress increment in axial direction is: (12) where, (13)
H=Dδáδin-δñ = damage modulus,
δ = normalized distance between f and F surfaces, Figure 2,
δin = maximum distance between F and fo surfaces, Figure 2, and
D = parameter used to control the shape of the peak.
Substituting all the terms in Equation (12), the final form of the incremental stress for a strain-controlled formulation becomes: (14)

Equation (14) gives the stress–strain relationship in an incremental form for the conventional triaxial test case. For the input of elasto-damage strain increments on the right hand side of the equation, the corresponding elasto-damage stress increments can be determined. These stress and strain increments are added to provide the predicted behavior. The elasto-damage behavior alone is not able to predict the actual behavior, due to the missing plastic strain component.

sec.title: Plastic Strain (Method 1)
sec.p: The total strain is assumed to be composed of elastic, damage, and plastic strains. In terms of principal strains in axial direction, ɛ1e is the elastic strain; ɛ1d is the damage strain resulting from the damage growth by the purely brittle elasto-damage theory, and ɛ1p is the plastic strain component that is to be added. The plastic strain is a nonlinear irrecoverable part, and is taken as a factor times the damage strain so that: (15) where Fp is a constant factor, which is determined by trial and error using experimental results.

At any stress value found by the elasto-damage formulation, the purely elastic part of the strain is found as: (16) where Eo is the initial modulus of elasticity value, which is free from damage effect.

The elastic strain (Equation (16)) is subtracted from the elasto-damage strain (which is an input in Equation (14)) and the damage strain is determined, from which the plastic strain can be obtained (Equation (15)). The flow chart for the FORTRAN program developed to code this model is shown in Figure 3. Figure 3.
Flow chart for elasto-plasto-damage FORTRAN code with plastic strains added by method 1.

sec.title: Drucker–Prager Model
sec.p: The Drucker–Prager model was used for finding the plastic strain by method 2. The Drucker–Prager failure criteria is given as: (17) where, α is the positive material parameter defining the yield criteria in J1 versus J2D space, and represents the slope of the straight line fit, k is the intercept of the yield envelope, J1 is the first invariant of the stress tensor, and J2D second invariant of the deviatoric stress tensor.

As long as the material is within the linear elastic range, the governing stress–strain equation for a general case is given by Desai and Siriwardane (1984), and it has the following form for the CTC test case: (18) where, Go is the initial shear modulus, and Ko is the initial bulk modulus of elasticity.

When the stress state reaches the yield envelope, the governing stress–strain equation for a general case is given by Desai and Siriwardane (1984), and it has the following form for the CTC test case in the axial direction: (19) where, Ti = A + Cσi, and Ri = Aσi + B, with i = 1, 2.
A and B are the factors depending on material parameters determined from the test results, and are given as: (20) (21) (22) (23) (24)

The plastic strain in this method was calculated using the Drucker–Prager model (Equation (18) or (19)), which is coded in a FORTRAN program, whose flow chart is shown in Figure 4. The total strain was assumed to be composed of elasto-damage and plastic strain. The elasto-damage strain and stress were determined using Equation (14). Figure 4.
Flow chart for execution of Drucker–Prager model for triaxial test.

sec.title: EXPERIMENTAL PROGRAM
sec.p:
In order to calibrate the model and to determine its parameters, an extensive experimental program was conducted. Tests were done on a cohesive soil (marl) collected from a site near the Dhahran area. The complete particle size distribution curve including the hydrometer analysis part is shown in Figure 5. The marl has a liquid limit of 56 and a plasticity index of 18.5. Modified Proctor compaction test was done on the marl, and the compaction curve is given in Figure 6. The maximum dry density, (ρd)max, and the optimum moisture content (O.M.C.) were found to be 1.539 g/cm3 and 27.3%, respectively. Figure 5.
Grain size distribution curve for marl. Figure 6.
Modified Proctor compaction curve with moisture density combinations.

Unconsolidated drained triaxial compression tests were performed at a cell pressure of 100, 200, 300, 400, and 500 kPa, for each case. Three samples were tested at (ρd)max and O.M.C. (case TM, Table 1) at each cell pressure, to achieve consistency and confidence in test results. For all other cases given in Table 1, two tests were done at each cell pressure. All items of apparatus were calibrated to ensure accurate measurements of stresses and strains.

Hydrostatic compression tests were conducted for each case to obtain the initial bulk modulus of elasticity (Ko). Isotropic cell pressures used were 25, 50, 100, 200, 400, 800, 1000 kPa for loading; and 800, 400, 200, 100, 50, 25 kPa for unloading. Three tests were conducted for the case TM, to assure repeatability and confidence in the test results. The three results are fairly close to each other, and therefore for the other density values one hydrostatic compression test was made. The cell chamber was calibrated to ensure accurate measurement of volume change of soil sample. For this purpose, a solid steel cylinder of the same size as the soil sample was used to measure the volume change due to the expansion of the cell. This volume change was subtracted from the apparent measured volume change of soil sample to obtain the actual volume change of the soil.
Unconfined compression tests were also performed on samples for different marl cases.

sec.title: RESULTS AND DISCUSSIONS
sec.p: The deviator stress and volumetric strain versus axial strain plots at different cell pressures were obtained for different marl cases. For all cases, a post peak strain-softening and volumetric dilatation behavior were observed. Hydrostatic compression test results for different marl cases were also obtained by potting hydrostatic stress versus volumetric strain. The unconfined compression tests results for different marl cases were also obtained by plotting the stress–strain curves.

sec.title: Elasto-Damage Model Parameters
sec.p: The expressions for the damage model parameters were determined from the experimental results, and then used in the computer program. These parameters are presented as follows:

sec.title: Initial Modulus of Elasticity (Eo)
sec.p:
Eo was obtained form the triaxial test results as the slope of the initial straight-line portion of the stress–strain curve, for various values of cell pressure (σ3). Normalized values of Eo versus σ3 with respect to atmospheric pressure (Pa = 101.325 kPa) are shown in Figure 7. The general expression for the fit is given as: (25) where, A is the intercept of the fit, and B is the slope of the fit. Figure 7.
Normalized initial modulus of elasticity vs normalized confining pressure.
Table 1 lists the values of A and B for different marl cases.

Initial modulus of elasticity from the results of the unconfined compression (UC) test varies with the unconfined compression strength (qu) of the soil, which is affected by the dry density. The Eo values obtained from the stress–strain curves for the UC test result were plotted versus qu (Figure 8), which have the following form: (26) Figure 8.
Initial modulus of elasticity for unconfined compression test.

sec.title: Peak Deviator and Shear Strength Parameters
sec.p: The shear strength parameters, cohesion (c) and the angle of internal friction (ϕ), were determined using the peak deviator stress value (Δσ1,p) at different cell pressures. Mohr-Coulomb failure envelopes for different marl cases were plotted. The values of shear strength parameters (c and ϕ for different cases are listed in Table 1. Using these values, the value of Δσ1,p can be expressed as: (27)

sec.title: Peak Shape Factor D
sec.p: This parameter is used to define the shape of the peak of the predicted stress–strain curves. The value of this factor was found, by trial and error. For both CTC and UC tests, different values of D were used at different density values, and Table 1 lists the appropriate values of this parameter for different cases.

sec.title: Strain Energy Release Rate at Onset of Damage (Ro)
sec.p: The value of Ro corresponds to the stress level at which the damage begins, and has units of kN.m/m3. The stress level at which the damage begins is taken as some percentage of the peak deviator stress. Ro was calculated using Equation (10) at 20% of the peak deviator stress value for all marl cases, and for both CTC and UC test cases. This was decided on the basis for comparing the predicted with experimental stress–strain data.

sec.title: Critical Strain Energy Release Rate (Rc)
sec.p: The values of Rc were calculated using Equation (11), and the minimum value of 0.1 kN.m/m3, which was determined from UC test data, was used for all other cases for both UC and CTC test results.

sec.title: Peak Deviator Strength Factor (β)
sec.p:
The β parameter is used to match the peak of the predicted stress–strain curve with the experimental curve. The value of β was found by trial and error. Figure 9 shows the variation of β versus peak deviator stress (σ1,p) for different marl cases, with the following general equation for the fit: (28) where,U is the intercept of the fit, and F is the slope of the fit. Figure 9.
Peak strength factor vs peak deviator strength for CTC.

Table 1 lists the values of U and F for different marl cases. The value of β depends on peak deviator strength of the material. For triaxial tests on marl, the value of β varies between 0.0002 and 0.002 for peak deviator strength (Δσ1,p) of 700–2500 kPa.

For the unconfined compression strength test, the peak of the stress–strain curve was matched using trial and error procedure. Figure 10 plots β versus qu for different marl cases, which has the following form: (29) Figure 10.
Peak strength factor vs qu.
For comparison purposes, Khan et al. (1998) used values for β between 0.03 and 0.08 for concrete having an unconfined compression strength (fc') of 55–66 MPa.

sec.title: Plastic Strain by Method 1
sec.p:
The plastic strain (ɛ1p) in method 1 was calculated as a factor (Fp) times the damage strain (ɛ1d) (Equation 15). The damage strain was calculated and then multiplied with the plastic strain factor (Fp) to obtain the plastic strain. The total strain was obtained by adding the plastic strain to the elasto-damage strain. Figure 11 shows the variation of Fp with σ3 for different marl cases, which indicates that Fp is proportional to σ3. The general expression for these fits is given as: (30) where, V is the intercept of the fit, and H is the slope of the fit. Figure 11.
Plastic strain factor vs σ3.
Table 1 lists the values of V and H for different marl cases.

Figure 12 shows comparisons between the CTC experimental and the simulated stress–strain curves for different marl cases. Also, Figure 13 shows a comparison between the predicted and the UC experimental stress–strain curves for different marl cases. The plastic strain was not added in this case, because there is not much plasticity due to the brittle behavior of the compacted marl. Figure 12.
Predicted and experimental curves by method 1 for marl case: (a) TM, (b) MM, (c) LM, (d) ON, (e) OM, and (f) OL. Figure 13.
Experimental and predicted curves for different marl cases for unconfined compression test case.

sec.title: Plastic Strain by Method 2
sec.p: The expression for the initial modulus of elasticity (Eo) is the same as that given by Equation (26). Other parameters required for this method are briefly given below.

sec.title: Initial Bulk Modulus (Ko)
sec.p: The values of Ko were found from the results of the hydrostatic compression tests. Table 1 gives the values of the initial bulk modulus for different marl cases.

sec.title: Poisson’s Ratio (ν) and Initial Shear Modulus (Go)
sec.p: The values of Eo and Ko were used to determine the values of the Poisson’s ratio (ν) and the initial shear modulus (Go) using the following elastic relationships: (31) (32)
These expressions were used in the FORTRAN program with the required inputs to calculate the values of these material parameters.

sec.title: Yield Envelope Parameters (α) and (k)
sec.p:
Figure 14 shows the Drucker–Prager yield envelopes for all marl cases. The yield envelope drawn between the first invariant of the stress tensor (J1) and the square root of the second invariant of the deviatoric stress tensor (J2D) is a straight-line fit. Table 1 lists the value of the parameters α and k (Equation (17)) for different marl cases. Figure 14.
Drucker–Prager yield envelopes.

sec.title: Total Elasto-Plastic Strain (εt)
sec.p:
One of the inputs used for finding plastic strains by the Drucker–Prager model is the total elasto-plastic strain (εt). At different cell pressures, the value of εt was obtained by trial and error by comparing the experimental stress–strain curve with the analytical one. The value of εt is used for determining the appropriate plastic strain component to be added to the elasto-damage strain component, in order to obtain the total strain. Figure 15 shows plots of εt versus σ3 for different marl cases. The general expression for a straight line fit passing through the origin is given as: (33) Table 1 lists the values of Z for different marl cases. Figure 15.
Total elasto-plastic strain factor vs confining pressure.

sec.title: Elasto-Plastic Residual Stress (σr)
sec.p:
This is used as an input for the determination of the plastic strains by Drucker–Prager model. Figure 16 shows plots of σr versus σ3 for different marl cases. The general expression for a straight-line fit is given as: (34) Table 1 lists the values of M and N for different cases. Figure 16.
Elasto-plastic residual strength vs confining pressure.

Using the above expressions for different parameters, the FORTRAN program was used to obtain the predicted curves by method 2, which were compared with experimental ones for different marl cases in Figure 17. Figure 17.
Predicted and experimental curves by method 2 for marl case: (a) TM, (b) MM, (c) LM, (d) ON, (e) OM, and (f) OL.

Figure 18 shows the importance of the plastic strains that need to be added to the elasto-damage strain to get the prediction that is closer to the experimental results. This figure also shows a comparison between the predicted curves by the two methods for the marl case OL at σ3 = 200 kPa cell pressure. Figure 18.
Effect of plastic strain on prediction.

sec.title: Comparison between Method 1 and Method 2
sec.p: In both the methods the elastic and damage strain components are found by using the elasto-damage formulation. The plastic strain is found as Fp times the damage strain in method 1, while it is calculated from the elasto-plastic Drucker–Prager model in method 2. The difference between the two methods is that in case of method 2 there is a sudden change in slope when plastic strains are added to the elasto-damage strains because of the behavior of the Drucker–Prager model. It can also be observed that the predictions by method 1 are slightly better than that by method 2. Method 2 on the other hand is theoretically sounder, because the plastic strain is evaluated from a rigorous elasto-plastic model. Both the methods validate each other.

Figure 19 shows the plots of Fp versus ωt for different marl cases. The general expression for the fit is given as: (35) where, S is the intercept of the fit, and W is the slope of the fit. Figure 19.
Relationship between Fp and εt.

Table 1 lists all the values of S and W for different marl cases along with their coefficients of determination (R2). The fact that Fp can be expressed in terms of ωt validates that plastic strains can be taken as a factor of damage strains. Although each one was calibrated separately and was obtained using a different model, there is still a relationship that exists between them.

sec.title: CONCLUSIONS
sec.p: A new elasto-plasto-damage model is presented for the stress–strain behavior of cohesive soils. The model is suitable for simulating the post-peak strain-softening stress–strain behavior of soil. The model combines elasto-damage strain and plastic strain to determine the total strain. Two different methods were used to find the plastic strain. The predictions by both methods are excellent, and able to identify all the features of the stress–strain behavior. The predictions by method 1 are smoother than those by method 2. Method 2 has a sudden change in slope of the predicted stress strain curves at the transition from elastic to elasto-plasto-damage behavior. Method 1 is very simple and needs fewer parameters to be calibrated, compared to method 2. Only conventional triaxial test data is required for the calculation of plastic strain. For method 2, isotropic compression test data is also required, in addition to conventional triaxial test data for the calculation of plastic strain by the Drucker–Prager model.

ack.title: ACKNOWLEDGMENTS
ack.p: The authors acknowledge the support of King Fahd University of Petroleum and Minerals for providing computing and laboratory facilities. The assistance of Professor Muhammad Hussain Baluch and Dr Asad-ur-Rehman Khan is greatly appreciated.
